> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/3112?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [c6bdaf8...d5370ac](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/3112?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).

So what happens.
- The record cannot be found anymore at a certain hearthbeat because it is deleted in the test 
- The job will terminate the bash_task_runner (jobs.py:2594)
- The bash_task_runner will terminate

In the case of the test there are no descendants:
```
bash,1
  ├─pstree,2213 -a -p
  └─pytest,2187 /usr/local/bin/pytest tests/core.py
      └─pytest,2203 /usr/local/bin/pytest tests/core.py
          ├─airflow,2205 /usr/local/bin/airflow run test_utils sleeps_forever 2015-01-01T00:00:00+00:00 --job_id 17 --raw -sd DAGS_FOLDER/example_dags/test_utils.py --cfg_path /tmp/tmpoiInKx
          └─{pytest},2206
```

After some tests I noticed that the exit handler is not invoked:
https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/blob/a5d9d5038b3ab59dcc1f64a1c161fb63f41c58cf/airflow/jobs.py#L2500

Maybe this is because we've changed the way of killing the processes.

I have a strong suspicion that the test is not working properly, when I run the individual test on master, I get the same result:
```

self = <tests.core.CoreTest testMethod=test_terminate_task>

    def test_terminate_task(self):
        """If a task instance's db state get deleted, it should fail"""
        TI = models.TaskInstance
        dag = self.dagbag.dags.get('test_utils')
        task = dag.task_dict.get('sleeps_forever')
    
        ti = TI(task=task, execution_date=DEFAULT_DATE)
        job = jobs.LocalTaskJob(
            task_instance=ti, ignore_ti_state=True, executor=SequentialExecutor())
    
        # Running task instance asynchronously
        p = multiprocessing.Process(target=job.run)
        p.start()
        sleep(5)
        settings.engine.dispose()
        session = settings.Session()
        ti.refresh_from_db(session=session)
        # making sure it's actually running
        self.assertEqual(State.RUNNING, ti.state)
        ti = session.query(TI).filter_by(
            dag_id=task.dag_id,
            task_id=task.task_id,
            execution_date=DEFAULT_DATE
        ).one()
    
        # deleting the instance should result in a failure
        session.delete(ti)
        session.commit()
        # waiting for the async task to finish
        p.join()
    
        # making sure that the task ended up as failed
        ti.refresh_from_db(session=session)

@sebradloff Sorry for late reply. 

In its current form, the MesosExecutor allows specifying static values for CPU & memory per task. When the airflow framework scheduler receives a resource offer from mesos master that has less resources than what is specified in this config, it rejects that offer. Or in other words, it accepts only those offers that have more or equal number of resources as mentioned in the config. But its a STATIC value. Same for all tasks for all DAGs. 
Now I'll preface this by saying I'm pretty new to airflow and specifically to the scheduler-foo logic but FWIK having able to specify cpu & memory per task for a DAG would require changes in airflow scheduler's code where it's creating `TaskInstance`s but it sounds like a suggestion worth exploring. 

Regarding having to specify both `docker` & `mesos` containerizers it looks like you are right. We need only one in this case - the `docker` one. Although I'm yet to try that out on my setup. Not getting enough bandwidth :( 

Thanks for the architectural diagram. I did create a [basic architectural diagram](http://agrajmangal.in/blog/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/airflow_mesos.png) in [my first blog post](http://agrajmangal.in/blog/big-data/running-airflow-on-top-of-apache-mesos/) on this subject - See http://agrajmangal.in/blog/wp-content/uploads/2018/01/airflow_mesos.png But I agree specifying more details like containers inside executors and webserver and scheduler also running on mesos slaves makes sense. Will update the blog post as soon as I find some time.

@Fokko please take a look when you get a chance?

@agrajm No worries on the late reply.

Your first point regarding CPU and memory per task makes sense. I think I will also have to do a deeper dive into airflow to understand how we could potentially change the amount of resources. 

Thanks for confirming my suspicions on the need for both `docker` and `mesos` containerizers.

Yea, your first blog post was great and opened up our eyes to the possibility of Mesos and airflow to begin with. The diagram was the confusing part from the sense of what was a container vs a VM.

One last thing, just to confirm my understanding. A new offer will be made to Mesos for each airflow task, in the code that you've written here, correct? I'm basing that off of your test code where you create two fake tasks and I see them being added to a tasks queue with the scheduler creating offers plural.

So let's see this from mesos POV - Airflow is just one framework registered with mesos amongst others ( like Marathon, Chronos, Aurora, Spark etc ). When a slave becomes free it notifies the mesos master and the mesos master ( based on its [allocation](http://mesos.apache.org/documentation/latest/allocation-module/) strategy ) then creates resource offers and send them to registered frameworks. 

So in our case airflow will receive some of these resource offers from Mesos master depending upon the allocator and how many resources are free, and then its upto the Airflow's MesosExecutor whether to accept or reject the offer. In its current form, the Mesos Executor has a queue where it has list of scheduled tasks and as it receives offers from Mesos master it checks for resources in that offer and if that resources value matches the expectations in the config then it accepts the offer and launches tasks on that mesos slave via master. Hope this clears it up.

@Fokko Yes, that is correct. When you submit a job, it uploads it to Cloud Storage in a temporary bucket it creates for that dataproc cluster.

Below is the location it uploads my pyspark job file `pi.py` when I run `gcloud dataproc jobs submit pyspark  pi.py --cluster=CLUSTER_NAME  --region=europe-west2`
```
gs://dataproc-272e8095-45e1-UUID-d4ed588428db-europe-west2/google-cloud-dataproc-metainfo/3ce3db05-a2dd-4f47-baba-c602e8d75e01/jobs/4ffd806b-c302-4931-905a-109ccd7d9be2/staging/pi.py
```

It also outputs the details of location of this file in the logs in the key: `mainPythonFileUri`:
```

You can also find the path of the temporary bucket created for dataproc cluster using `project.regions.clusters.get` on dataproc resource under `config.configBucket`

Check: https://cloud.google.com/dataproc/docs/reference/rest/v1/projects.regions.clusters#ClusterConfig

You can use an alternate approach to upload this file i.e. instead of uploading it to a bucket use the temporary bucket created for the DataProc cluster by first doing a get on the respective cluster and retrieving the name of the temporary bucket.

However, I think the idea of having a temporary bucket for Airflow makes more sense and this bucket can be used for multiple things.
